physical_findings: Posterior uveitis with disseminated choroiditis (most common)
Multiple, discrete, yellow lesions in the posterior pole
Single large choroidal tuberculomas (with or without retinal detachment and macular star formation)
risk_factors: Prior exposure to acutely infected individual

imaging_findings.Fluorescein angiography: Early hypofluorescence of active choroiditis and late leakage; Cicatricial lesions show early blocked hyperfluorescence with late staining
imaging_findings.Indocyanine green angiography: Early and late-stage hypofluorescence of the lesions; Subclinical lesions may be seen
imaging_findings.Ultrasonography: Moderate to low internal reflectivity of large tuberculomas; Can distinguish them from intraocular malignancy
imaging_findings.Chest X-ray/CT: May be negative in half of patients with extrapulmonary involvement
imaging_findings.Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Shows macular edema, which may resolve with treatment

required: Clinical presentation consistent with tuberculous uveitis (e.g., granulomatous anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis with disseminated choroiditis)
supportive: Positive tuberculin skin test (PPD) or interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA)
Positive chest X-ray or CT scan suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis
